data.title: William Henry (Hannover) Hanover (1765-1837)
meta_keywords: family tree of William IV Hannover
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for William IV (Hannover) Hanover born 1765 Buckingham House, Westminster, Middlesex, England died 1837 Windsor Castle, Windsor, Berkshire, England including ancestors + descendants + 2 photos + 4 genealogist comments + questions + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 11 Aug 2024 | Created 9 Mar 2013

This page has been accessed 11,867 times.

Biography

William IV (Hannover) Hanover is a member of the House of Hanover.

In the penultimate year of his life and reign as King William IV of the United Kingdom, he appointed Rear-Admiral Sir John Hindmarsh KH RN, also a Royal Navy man, as the first Governor of the new Colony of South Australia, "William IV, having been empowered by an Act of Parliament in August 1834, [and] in February 1836 Letters Patent 'Erected and Established' the Province of South Australia"[1]. Hindmarsh's term of appointment was to commence 28 December 1836, and ended after 1 year and 200 days on 16 July 1838.

The Governor was given those written orders from King William IV, known as The Letters Patent, "which expressly sought to protect ... [the] ... traditional rights to land and resources [of the existing inhabitants] in the following words: '… Provided Always that nothing in those our Letters Patent contained shall affect or be construed to affect the rights of any Aboriginal Natives of the said Province to the actual occupation or enjoyment in their own Persons or in the Persons of their Descendants of any Lands therein now actually occupied or enjoyed by such Natives'[2]. Ref.1 confirms that "Hindmarsh ... stated that Aborigines were to be treated justly and were 'equally entitled to the privileges of British subjects'. However, the Resident Commissioner, James Hurtle Fisher[3] and the Secretary of State for the Colonies clearly had other plans, and Hindmarsh was sent back home in 1838, after the death of William IV in 1837, no doubt influenced by the wealthy merchants of the South Australian Company[4]that had been established in 1835.

Sources

↑ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Hindmarsh

↑ https://www.adelaide.edu.au/press/system/files/media/documents/2020-07/uap-natural-history-cllmm-ebook.pdf

↑ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Hurtle_Fisher

↑ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australian_Company

Wikipedia: William IV of the United Kingdom

Luke Mosley, Qifeng-Ye, Scoresby Shepherd, Steve Hemming, Rob Fitzpatrick, Editors, 2018, 'Natural History of the Coorong, Lower Lakes, and Murray Mouth Region (Yarluwar-Region)'. Royal Society of South Australia, Inc., University of South Australia, Adelaide, Press.

See also:

'Jane Austen's Family through Five Generations' by Maggie Lane, published by Robert Hale Limited, London. ISBN 0 7090 4832 7. Includes extensive family trees. Details of contemporaries and other connections are also mentioned in the text.Jane Austen's Family through Five Generations
